corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: James McNamara was an organizer and served in a number of staff positions for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in the 1950s and 1960s.  He then went on to hold a variety of positions at the New York City and state levels in which he engaged in negotiations, enforcement and investigative activities in relation to the building trades and the construction industry.  He worked on investigations for the New York State Organized Crime Task Force and the New York County District Attorney's Office (Labor Racketeering Unit) before his retirement in 1992.  The collection contains background material and legal files relating to investigations of the Carpenters, Mason Tenders, Painters, Plumbers, Service Employees (Local 32 B-J), Operating Engineers, Elevator Constructors and New York area Teamsters unions.  Also included are files on jurisdictional matters relating to the Building Trades Employers Association and files on the investigation of Brian McLaughlin as president of the New York City Central Labor Council.

p.value: Identification of item, date; James McNamara Papers; WAG 129; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

James McNamara sent a gift of his papers in several installments in 1996. The accession number associated with this gift is 1996.022. Tamiment Library received an additional two boxes of James McNamara's papers in 2011. The accession number associated with this gift is 2011.138.

He has served as an expert witness in numerous cases involving discrimination and corruption in the building trades and construction industry. He has been at the center of the major struggles for the last quarter century in New York City involving the effort to open up the building trades unions to minority workers and to women, along with the repeated efforts of government agencies to clean up corruption in the industry.  His wife, Ann Cadmus McNamara, an attorney, was General Counsel, New York City Department of Employment.

The collection is rich in research materials related to corruption within New York City local labor unions; union leaders were prosecuted for racketeering, bribery, embezzlement, no-show jobs, vote-fixing, and organized crime involvement. They were often indicted under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act or by the Organized Crime Task Force (OCTF). The materials also reflect investigations of discrimination of minorities in unions. The materials show how the media covered the scandals, as well as demonstrating how McNamara was involved in the prosecution. There is little personal materials related to McNamara and the collection mostly contains his work compiling research materials on the union.

corpname.value: United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America

dsc.value:
Series I: United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America1970-1999Scope and Content Note

This series includes materials from investigations into corruption in New York City's District Council of Carpenters dating back to District Council President Ted Maritas. This includes the indictment and related cases. Maritas disappeared and his body was never found. However, his wallet and car were found alongside the East River. The trail of corruption and records of litigation continue through the successive government cases against District Council President Paschal McGuinness, who resigned from his office and was barred from seeking union office in New York City (he held an executive position within the International Brotherhood of Carpenters), and Fred Devine (found guilty on racketeering charges; case on appeal). Materials include indictments, memoranda, correspondence, transcripts of hearings, and reports of the Independent Review Officer (I.R.O.) charged with oversight in the District Council. Other noteworthy documents in the series include the transcripts of the hearings on corruption at the Jacob Javits Center (Fiorino); the indictment and related records related to the shooting of Carpenters' official John O'Connor; and the repeated efforts of outspoken members to secure their rights within the union (Macaluso; Clarke; Local 608 hiring hall case). Additional examples of graft and corruption can be found in the records of (former) Bronx Local 17 (Shepis; Moscatiello).

Arrangement

Arranged alphabetically.

United Brotherhood of Carpenters1992249Series II: Mason Tenders Local of the Laborers International Union of North America (LIUNA)1985-1996Scope and Content Note

This series is comprised of records pertaining to racketeering in the Mason Tenders Local of the Laborers International Union of North America (LIUNA), New York City. They document legal actions connected to the Consent Decree entered into by the union in 1994. The outstanding example of testimony related to the case is that of Sammy "the Bull" Gravano, the most famous (and most productive) mobster to testify for the government. Records related to Lou Moscatiello and the declaration of Attorney Roger Levin provide examples of the systemic nature of corruption in the industry.

Messera, James et al.: Outline of Indictments1990329Series III: International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, District Council 91967-1995Scope and Content Note

This series contains records relating to the long history of corruption and mob control of the International Brotherhood of Painters, District Council 9 in New York City. Repeated efforts to clean up the union have met with failure. The records include correspondence, transcripts of wire taps; indictments; briefs and trial transcripts, along with additional material from active union members related to the internal life of the union (elections; opposition newspapers, flyers, etc.). Press clippings detail the history of mob control and racketeering. Records related to Lou Moscatiello, Bronx mobster, are also included in this series.

Moscatiello, Lou (II)1995415Racketeering1990, 1995416Union Publications1978, 1991417Series IV: United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipefitting Industry, Plumbers Local 2 (Manhattan)1964-1997Scope and Content Note

This series contains records related to the government investigation and trial against the officials of Plumbers union, Local #2, Manhattan. After an early morning raid on the offices and homes of top officials, most were tried, convicted and went to jail. The records include press clippings, progress reports, and Department of Labor reports on finances (LM-2s) and the trusteeship (LM-15s). The legal records and briefs document the pattern of corruption in the industry, as does the report "Enforcement Down the Drain." An important chapter of internal union activity is found in the materials related to the 1996 election in Local 2. The unusually high degree of membership participation and the government efforts to clean up the local were undone when the International merged the local out of existence; members of Local #2 now found themselves in Local #1 (Ozone Park, Queens).

Arrangement

Arranged alphabetically.

Clippings and Press1964, 1967, 1992-1996418Constitutions1989-1991419Correspondence1993-1996420Department of Labor: Annual Reports1994-1997421Department of Labor: Trusteeship Reports1993-1996422Election Materials1996423Government Surveillance: Progress Report (I)1991424Government Surveillance: Progress Report (II)1991425Hearing of Local 21993426Legal Briefs and Indictments1988-1993427Legal Briefs and Indictments1994-1995428Legal Briefs and Indictments1996429Licensing: Public Advocate Report, "Enforcement Down The Drain"1996430Series V: Service Employees International Union, Local 32 B-J1954-1999Scope and Content Note

This series includes records that document a rank-and-file campaign within the 32B-J to challenge the corruption of local union officials. The efforts of the reformers led to the ousting of Gus Bevona as president of 32B-J. Bevona had the distinction of being the highest paid union leader in the country (see LM-2s). He was removed by his international president, Andrew Stern, after the reformers succeeded in raising repeated challenges through a variety of campaigns centered on by-law reforms. The corruption within officialdom was given additional exposure with the conviction of business agent McGorman for selling jobs to members. The reformers' campaign to provide background information to the sentencing judge is documented in the collection.

Arrangement

Arranged alphabetically.

This series consists of records documenting various phases of corruption as well as rank-and-file opposition activity in New York area Teamsters locals. Included are files on Local 807 (the Javits Center local), Tony Salerno and Local 272 (the parking garage local), the government's case against Barry Feinstein of Local 237, the report issued by the Independent Review Officer on Teamster leader Ron Carey, and Susan Jennik's brief for the Association for Union Democracy (submitted in relation to U.S. v. IBT, the so-called "Cosa Nostra" case).

IBT, "La Cosa Nostra" et al.1992527Series VII: Building Trades Employers' Association of the City of New York1945-1997Scope and Content Note

This series includes materials related to the Association concerning jurisdictional disputes between the building trades. Also included are files on jurisdictional matters relating to the Building Trades Employers Association and files on the investigation of Brian McLaughlin as president of the New York City Central Labor Council.

Jurisdictional Disputes: Correspondence1945, 1978-1979, 1989528Jurisdictional Disputes: Plans1976, 1997529Series VIII: 2002-2011 Addenda1990s-2010Arrangement

This series has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

Scope and Content Note

This series contains materials donated by McNamara over multiple accessions between 2002 and 2011, dating from the 1980s to the 2000s. The bulk of the materials in the series are related to the United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipefitting Industry (UA) New York City Local 1 scandal and the scandals within the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America New York City locals. The New York City District Council of the Carpenters union was indicted multiple times throughout the 2000s, which is evidenced throughout this addenda. Other unions that were investigated include the International Union Of Elevator Constructors Local 1, Service Employees International Union Local 32 B-J (especially the investigation of Gus Bevona), AFSCME District Council 37, International Longshoremen's Association, United Union Of Roofers, Waterproofers And Allied Workers Local 8, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 3, International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 36, and the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 14/15.

The types of materials found in this series include clippings, court proceedings, transcripts, handwritten notes, correspondence, Association for Union Democracy correspondence and newsletters, union election materials, drafts of articles, photographs, and other materials. Within folders, there is a mix of handwritten notes by McNamara with some annotated clippings, correspondence, and other materials. Most of the material is related to corruption within the unions, but a huge portion of documents are related to discrimination within unions, especially in hiring halls. McNamara focused on both race and gender related discrimination in labor unions.

Box 61990s-2000s6Scope and Content Note

This box contains materials from the 1990s-2000s, related to McNamara's work in researching anti-corruption cases in labor unions. It includes the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act lawsuit against the New York City District Council of Carpenters; the AFSCME District Council 37 vote-fixing and embezzlement scandal, which led to the arrests of union executives Stanley Hill, Albert Diop, and Martin Lubin (among others); Brian McLaughlin of the New York City Central Labor Council (NYCCLC) racketeering case, who embezzled $185,000 from the NYCCLC; and cases related to gender and minority discrimination in unions and hiring halls. These materials are made up of newspaper clippings, court proceedings, newsletters (including copies of Committee for Real Change in DC 37), interoffice memoranda, correspondence, flyers, handwritten notes by McNamara, a Citizens Committee for James McNamara for City Council pamphlet, and other ephemera.

Box 71990s-2000s7Scope and Content Note

This box contains materials on equal opportunity in union apprenticeship training and minority rights in the building industry, health and hospital building trades employment, the RICO suit against the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA) in 2005, materials on ILA local 1588, clippings on the John Gotti trial and mob involvement on the waterfront, ILA convention materials, and other materials related to the ILA (McNamara worked as a spokesman for the union.)

This bulk of the material in the box is related to the United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters (UA) including materials related to the Tom Preuett campaign for union president, by-laws, collective bargaining agreements, election materials, and contracts, materials related UA President Martin Maddaloni and Secretary-Treasurer Thomas Patchell ousting after reckless pension investments, the UA Local 1 training school scandal in 2006, New York v. Figliolia Plumbing (Metropolitan Transit Authority wage theft) materials, UA Local 1 indictments including Organized Crime Task Force indictments in the UA Local 2 (which eventually merged into the Local 1), and the De-Con Mechanical Contractors tax evasion.

The box also contains materials related to two separate Urban Labor Life Insurance Company (ULLICO) scandals in 2002. The first of which was a conflict of interest scandal, in which the Carpenters union hired a subsidiary of ULLICO, Zenith Administrators, to handle their pension and benefit funds. The other was an insider trading scandal with Global Crossing and ULLICO officers.

Other union materials include an agreement between General Contractions Association an Local 731 of the Laborers International Union of North America (LIUNA) and the Roofers Local 8 District Attorney indictment for extortion (eventually part of the bribe money would go to the Genovese Crime Family).

Box 81980s-2000s8Scope and Content Note

This box contains materials on Mike Crimi (a Genovese Family mafia associate) involvement in carpenters employments associations. It also includes materials on the Roofers Union Local 8 bribery case, investigation materials on 32BJ President Gus Bevona (possible embezzlement of union funds), and Community Coalition indictments, including a court transcript for the United States v. Matthew Taylor. Community coalitions were groups that represented minority workers battling racial bias in buildings industry; they were indicted for extortion and mob ties.

This box contains a significant amount of material involving International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) Local 3 and International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT) Local 363. This material includes court papers involving a legal battle between the two unions, and discrimination and hiring hall investigations in both unions. The materials include Tom Carlough's of the IBT Local 363 testimony to the New York City Human Rights Commission, testimony of Local 3's president Thomas Van Ardsdale, RICO Act case court proceedings, and other investigations on the construction industry in New York City by the New York City Commission on Human Rights and the New York City Office of Labor Services.

Other materials include materials on Carpenters Union RICO Act case (McCarron v. Devine), a discrimination case in the Elevator Constructors Local 1, Operating Engineers Local 14/15 Indictments (hiring of "no work" workers), and a Carpenters Local 608 bribe case in 2005.

Box 91990s-2000s9Scope and Content Note

The bulk of the materials in the box are related to the New York City District Council, United Brotherhood of Carpenters corruption cases, including the indictment of Michael Forde (Executive Secretary Treasurer), other union leaders, and mobsters in September 2000 for racketeering, bribery, and bid-rigging; Local 157's take over by the national union in 2007; 2009 indictment and press release of New York City District Council officials; Forde's guilt plea and sentencing to racketeering, obstruction of justice, and illegal payments in 2010.

The box also contains more materials on the 32BJ President Gus Bevona investigation; articles written by McNamara for the Association for Union Democracy; indictment of officials in the Local 40 of the Structural Ironworkers Union and Mario Mastromarino, a member of the Gambino crime family; Roofers Union Local 8 conviction in 2006, McNamara's testimony to the New York State Commission of Investigation, Public Hearings; more materials on the Brian McLaughlin embezzlement case; a significant amount of clippings and reports on discrimination in building trades, and a discrimination case between Joyce Collier and the Local 1 of the Plumbers Union.

There is also materials on the RICO act indictment of the leadership of District Council 9 (DC9) of the Painters Union in the early 1990s and the murder of James Bishop, a DC9 leader.

Box 101990s-2000s10Scope and Content Note

This box contains materials from the corruption scandals in the UA Plumbers Union, Local 1, including a Department of Transportation investigation; investigation of Donald Sclafani, a business manager for the Local 1; Collier v. Plumbers Union; Kroll Risk Consulting Company reports of the Local 1; and the New York State Organized Crime Task Force agreement in December 2003.

The box also includes the District Council of New York City Carpenters Union testimony of Kenneth McCabe and indictment of members of the Locals 14/15 of the Operating Engineers Union in connection with racketeering by organized crime in 2003 and discrimination investigations in Locals 14/15.
